reviewText:
The video trailer in my opinion gives a pretty poor opinion about what this game is actually like.  It's a combo based action game like Devil May Cry or similar types of stuff.  You have a basic combo or whatever, and then eventually it'll end, but you can switch characters to keep the combo going.  There are skills that will help you follow enemies and keep the hit count up.  Every so often, you hit a combo threhshold that permanently increases your damage by 10%, so the better your combos, the more damage you do.  You lose significant damage buff if you get hit, so it's a win=win more, lose=lose harder type of rewarding system that really plays to the type of person who can attack enemies relentlessly while not getting hit in the process because mindless button mashing.

This is actually the second Anima: Beyond Fantasy based Video Game.  The first is called Anima: Ark of Sinners, but it is a totally separate side story that has nothing to do with this game.  If you're not familiar with Anima: Beyond Fantasy, a lot of people will probably tell you it's some Final Fantasy-inspired P&P RPG, but the truth is, it's got way more inspiration from Xenogears than anything else.  There is quite a bit of backstory that players not familiar with the RPG won't know about, but they are not necessary to understand the plot of the game.  The significance of some characters like Romeo Exxet might be lost on you, but overall it's not a huge deal to the plot of the game itself.

It has a slow start, but it's very good if you give it a chance.  After the first few stages is when you unlock the game proper and gain access to skill trees for both characters and such.  It has a little RPG style elements, obviously, but it's still predominantly an action game.  I highly recommend checking this out.  If you like the game and want more, I highly recommend checking out the P&P Anima: Beyond Fantasy game which is among one of my favorite P&P RPGs.  Just be aware it's a Spanish game, the English-translation is kind of mediocre, and being European, the rules are fairly crunchy.

reviewText:
I've played about 5 hours of the game, and here's what I think:

The bad.
The Voice acting. It's all over the place and very little of it is good. It's tolerable, sure, but it could have been so much better.
The combat is kind of dull. I really dug the idea of switching back and forth between the characters, but untill I have the chance to unlock the later tiers of abilities, I don't know how fun that will actually be.

The good.
The music is wonderful and fits the atmosphere of the various areas perfectly.
The overall setting and atmosphere of the game is wonderfully presented.
The story is familiar enough to ease me into the world of Anima, but unique enough to keep me interested.

Overall, this is a good, if just shy of great, game. There's some slight technical issues that I'd like to see addressed. (Why can't I use the D pad in menus on my 360 controller?) but they are annoyances, and nothing too serious.

I'd say, if you want to try a bizzare cross between and older Devil May Cry game and a traditional JRPG, this is worth $20.

reviewText:
Great Game  (3rd of June 2016 review)

Normally i rate my games on their choice of music and whether it fits in with the theme but this game's music is absolutely outstanding. The game is so beautiful i took 50 screenshots within the first hour of playing it. The story is interesting,  You begin your journey as the bearer who is a female that has been cursed with the power of a monster that you are told wanted to destroy the world. This monster was sealed away in a book and given to the bearer for her to unlock his hidden powers and use them to stop the woman in red. You are then taken away to a place that limits your powers meaning you need to unlock them one by one through levelling up.  You find many pieces of text telling the background of the messengers which are needed to be read in some areas in order to progress, the puzzles are fun and the platforming is great.

Another interesting thing this game includes is it's use of camera angles. The normal camera angle when you're roaming is 3rd person but sometimes when you enter a room, the game likes to switch it up and make the view top-down for the room, or another time you're searching for a way to go and you enter this area which gives you a 3D side-scroller camera angle. It's interesting to see the game from different angles when you're beating up enemies, especially since it's in 3D whilst giving you the usuall 2D camera views.

There are a few bugs here and there,  such as for example climbing up onto some rubble and then jumping out of the map through the gap in the building within the cathedral in the 2nd messenger's area  or enemies not being able to walk down a set of stairs making them get stuck and easily killed with magic abilities, but those are probably going to be fixed soon.

In conclusion, looks pretty, including a launcher that you can set your graphics settings, amazing music and an interesting story with good voice acting, however the protagonist female could have been done much better i think. The main things that bother me are that i cannot have 1920x1200 graphics on windowed mode, only allows up to 1680x1050, the there is no windowed borderless mode, a few bugs which need to be fixed since they can get you out of the map and when reading the stories of the messengers, the female's narration is different from the text. Which can get very confusing sometimes and you can get lost in the text. Other than that the game is a must buy for Anime RPG lovers. reviewText:
Well, this game was a bit less optimized than I expected, but after getting it to play properly I can say I don't hate it and it did not fall flat in terms of my expectations. It certainly displays how Anima feels with the casual use of existential barriers and destruction on a temporal level and offers an interesting perspective lorewise. The Bearer's voice is very flat for a protagonist, no wonder she's got no name, but I personally enjoy the likes of Ergo Mundus's lewdness and Zero Mask being voiced by Cr1tikal/Charlie, as well as Romeo Exxet's narration. Combat is enjoyable, though I'm admittedly not the best at this. The camera sensitivity on a mouse and keyboard really is insane though, I had to drop it to about -36 to get it to an acceptable level of not spinning my screen three times with every motion, but it being a fixable problem is good enough for me to give it a pass. It's still awkward on a keyboard set-up for me but that's my personally being better with controllers than a game fault.

The art style is questionable in some areas, primarily some of the faces, but the environment looks beautiful and I don't mind the models after sufficient exposure. I'm disappointed this game didn't get all the funding it wanted and it shows with freeze framed cutscenes and nowhere near all 21 Messengers being actually within this game, though at least a respectable selection of ones yet to be revealed in-depth within the tabletop were chosen. All in all, the plot offers an interesting perspective of the Empire's ♥♥♥♥ed situation and characterizes several important figures in Gaia, while simultaneously making for an engaging story so far.

reviewText:
The game is surprising.  Based on a Franchise of tabletop games (Anima: Beyond Fantasy being the TRPG), Anima: Gate of Memories is an attempt at an action RPG that is an excellent game for the price.

Pros:
Fun action gameplay
Interesting enemies
PRETTY AS ALL ♥♥♥♥
Neat little level-up tree for each character, allowing you to spec them out as you choose
A good amount of time, I estimate I am 1/6th or 1/7th of the way through the game.

Cons:
Voice Acting needs work - the voice actors seem to lack direction at times, or are unsure of context.
Occasional bugs - I have had two bugs that required me to revert to a checkpoint and one CTD.  That said, the game autosaves frequently, mitigating the effects of this
Needs optimization - The 'Pretty as all ♥♥♥♥' comes at a clear cost.  I was dropping frames regularily during my gameplay, though my graphics card is out of date and I was also streaming at the time.  Still, it could use some work on that end probably.


I'd give this a 7.5/10 overall, and a 9/10 in its price category.  Better games exist, but not for 20 bucks canadian (probably about 15 USD)

This game is so, so, so pretty. That part alone almost makes up for all the other failures. Almost...

I was a backer of this game, and let me tell you, with a two years delay and the amount of money they got, I was expecting so much more. The story takes a while to get into, the voice acting physically hurts my ears and the combat is meh. It doesn't make you care about the characters at all, and the RPG aspect is pretty weak. And boy, is it pretentious, with it's complicating sounding names and cliche mythology.

Extra complaint: The dialog between characters switches constantly from a fixed 2D portrait of them talking (like a dating sim) to a pseudo animation in 3D that only shows the end frames. Yeah, it's a minor issues, but the inconsistency is driving me up the wall.

I'd give it a 5/10.
